awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Impact of Freeway Geometric Design on Congestion Characteristics
awd_abstract_narration:
The objective of this Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) program award is to establish the relationship between freeway design elements, such as grade and curvature, and traffic congestion characteristics, such as the frequency of stop-and-go movements, hysteresis and capacity drop. The research approach is based on empirical data analysis, both existing and collected as part of this project. Vehicle trajectory data will be used to correlate congestion characteristics and individual driver behavior using a combination of numerical simulations and statistical analyses. This will allow for the unveiling of the link between driver behavior and freeway design, and to propose and validate a car-following theory able to capture the findings in this research. 

If successful, the results of this research will lead to improved freeway design guidelines, which currently mostly focus on providing adequate capacity. This research will provide answers to questions such as: How should we design freeways so that, when congested, (i) the number of acceleration/deceleration maneuvers is minimized?, or (ii) the bottleneck discharge rate is maximized?, or (iii) the number of lane-changes is minimized? The answer to these questions will potentially help minimize greenhouse gases, commuter delays and accidents, and will promote a more sustainable infrastructure system in the future. Additionally, this research will provide practitioners and researchers with arguably the first traffic flow model able to capture complex congestion phenomena as observed empirically. This will improve the accuracy of existing freeway infrastructure project simulation-based assessments, and will allow testing more efficient congestion control strategies that focus on minimizing emission levels, delays and accidents. The educational and outreach objectives include an on-line portal for promoting traffic flow theory, simulation and modeling, where a community of students, researchers and industry professionals will benefit. This portal includes weekly webinars, data and program tools, a discussion forum and a wiki.

por.por_cntn:
This Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) program award established the relationship between freeway design elements, such as grade and curvature, and traffic congestion characteristics, such as the frequency of stop-and-go movements, hysteresis and capacity drop. The research approach was based on empirical data analysis, both existing and collected as part of this project. Vehicle trajectory data was used to correlate congestion characteristics and individual driver behavior using a combination of numerical simulations and statistical analyses. This allowed us to unveil the link between driver behavior and freeway design, and to propose and validate a car-following theory able to capture these findings.

We have shown that the formation and propagation of stop-and-go tra?c oscillations in the absence of lane changes can be explained by the stochastic error of drivers’ acceleration processes,  and that this error is related to the roadway geometry. This new theory suggests that driver error increases with roadway grade, and that it responsible for the formation and propagation of stop-and-go driving. 

This theory led to arguably the first traffic flow model able to capture complex congestion phenomena as observed empirically. The attached figure shows a time-space diagram of the median lane from the NGSIM trajectory dataset collected on a 640 m-segment on southbound US 101 in Los Angeles, CA, on June 15th, 2005 between 7:50 a.m. and 8:35 a.m. Note how the proposed simulation model is able to capture the formation and propagation of the stop-and-go driving waves shown in red.

The proposed theory will improve the accuracy of existing freeway infrastructure project simulation-based assessments, and will allow testing more e?cient congestion control strategies that focus on minimizing emission levels, delays and accidents. The impacts of these findings in the traffic flow community are already being felt, as several publications have already cited our work.

This project also contributed improved our understanding of traffic flow models, as documented in several peer-review journal publications. These findings led to numerical solution methods for traffic flow models that are devoid of numerical errors. This is important because standard numerical methods can produce important biases compared to the exact solution of a particular problem. We also identified a symmetry of traffic flow models that opens the door for alternative exact numerical solution methods.

The educational and outreach results include an on-line portal (http://trafficlab.ce.gatech.edu/) for promoting tra?c ?ow theory, simulation and modeling, where a community of students, researchers and industry professionals can bene?t. This portal includes data, course notes and interactive program tools. This project started the “Tra?c flow webinars” series consisting of approximately monthly webinars by students and faculty members around the world. Due to the success of this series, it has become part of the Tra?c Flow Theory and Characteristics Committee (AHB45) of the Transportation Research Board. The students involved in this project have been instrumental in organizing these webinars. 

This project partially funded the PhD thesis of underrepresented groups: two female students, as well as the MS thesis of a Hispanic male student.
